title: The powerful ingredient the $55b perfume industry banks on
text:
Natalie Reilly Writer Aug 30, 2019 — 12.15am Share

The olfactory nerve, located at the back of the nose, is the place where receptor neurons transmit information about smell to the brain. It’s where odours, once inhaled, are given context and meaning, then filed away as part of our personal history.

It’s why seemingly ordinary sensory details – freshly mowed grass, drops of rain – can throw us into a tumult of nostalgia, why a spritz of your grandmother’s signature scent is strangely transcendent. Memories surface when we smell whatever gripped us at the time. It’s one reason the global fragrance industry is valued at $56 billion – our deepest emotions are swirling around in those bottles.

It’s not surprising, then, that early-childhood memories are behind two of the world’s most famous fragrances: Coco Chanel’s iconic No. 5 and Christian Dior’s first fragrance, Miss Dior. They’re both inspired by gardens the fashion designers spent time in as children.

Chanel’s rose garden was located in a convent orphanage in central France, where she lived from age 12 after her mother’s death. Dior’s roses, meanwhile, were planted by his mother at the family’s holiday house on the cliffs of Normandy.

Coco Chanel’s iconic No. 5 was inspired by the roses in the garden of the convent orphanage she lived in.

These beginnings have been woven into the mythology of both brands, with great success. This June, Chanel released its annual earnings for 2018; total sales exceeded $US11 billion ($16.3 billion), thanks in large part to the growth of its fragrance and beauty sector.

Chanel’s longevity lies largely in its ability to layer modern interpretations over traditional product lines. The late Karl Lagerfeld knew this better than most: Chanel No. 5 never dies, it only morphs into moisturiser, shower gel and hair mist, before it splinters again into triplets: “The Woody”, “The Fresh” and “The Sensual”, varieties of No. 5 that were released in 2016.

Miss Dior was named after the designer's sister, Catherine, a spy in World War II who was captured and sent to a German concentration camp.

Through it all, the mythology remains. Few are unfamiliar with the story. It was 1920, dawn of the Jazz Age, and Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel wanted a fragrance for the modern woman. Her perfumer, Russian-born chemist Ernest Beaux, handed her vials with differing scents – and she picked the fifth one.

Chanel unofficially launched No. 5 in 1921 in a restaurant in Grasse, France. It’s the same place Dior’s roses are harvested today (nine kilos of pink petals for one bottle, in fact) for a scent whose moniker emerged from heroism during wartime.
description: It takes more than the link between memory and smell to keep a luxury fragrance making millions for decades – or even centuries – after it was created.
